title: Detecting single cell interferon-beta production using a fluorescent reporter telomerase-immortalized human fibroblast cell line
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Virus infection
Timing: 36 h
Cells respond to microbe-associated molecular patterns by upregulating IFN and IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Particles of Sendai virus (SeV) and human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) trigger an IFN response in the absence of virus replication and have been used extensively to study innate antiviral defense pathways. To examine the proportion of infected cells that upregulate IFN-ß in response to virus particles, we infected IFN-GFP THF cells with live or non-replicating UV-inactivated SeV (SeV-UV) or HCMV (HCMV-UV) particles.
Seed cells for immunofluorescence and flow cytometry
Using sterile forceps, transfer glass coverslips soaked in 70% ethanol to a 12-well plate and wash the coverslips with PBS before adding cell suspension
Add 1.5 × 106 THF IFN-GFP cells in 10 mL to 10 cm dishes and 1 × 105 THF IFN GFP cells in 1 mL per well to coverslips in 12-well plates and incubate 16–24 h
Note: THF IFN-GFP cells should reach ∼90% confluency the next day
Remember to seed an extra well and an extra plate for cell counting the next day
Note: Coverslips may be included in count wells if the coverslip is thought to affect cell count
Note: If cells do not adhere well to glass coverslips refer to troubleshooting 3 - Cells fail to adhere[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5].
Infect cells with live or inactivated SeV and HCMV
Dissociate and re-suspend cells in the count well with trypsin-EDTA and count cells using a glass hemocytometer
Dilute SeV to 2 plaque-forming units (pfu)/cell and HCMV to 0.3 pfu/cell in minimal volume of serum-free medium (0.3 mL/well for 12-well plates and 2 mL/dish for 10 cm dishes)
Add 0.5 mL of diluted virus per well to a 12-well plate and expose virus to a pre-optimized amount of UV-radiation in a stratolinker UV cross-linker

Remove medium from cells and add live or UV-inactivated virus
Incubate cells at 37°C for 1 h, rocking plates periodically (10–15 min) to prevent cells from drying out
Replace medium containing inactivated virus with 1 mL/well and 10 mL/plate maintenance medium (2% FBS DMEM) and incubate for 16–24 h while GFP is expressed and accumulates in cells.
Note: UV-inactivation should be pre-optimized to reduce infectious titer by >105 fold, or to where there is <1 plaque-forming unit per treatment condition. If you encounter difficulty with UV-inactivation refer to troubleshooting 4 - Ineffective UV-inactivation[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7].
Note: We have included a sample calculation for diluting SeV

Detecting IFN production by flow cytometry
Timing: 3 h

Flow cytometry can be used to easily quantify the level and frequency of IFN producing cells in a population. To quantify upregulation of IFN and ISG15 in individual cells we used flow cytometry of fixed cells with intracellular staining.
Fix and permeabilize cells
Wash THF cells in 10 cm dishes with PBS and incubate with 2 mL of trypsin-EDTA at 37°C until thoroughly dissociated
Resuspend dissociated cells in sorting buffer and pellet at 500 × g and 4°C for 5 min
Resuspend cell pellet in 100 μL of Cytofix/Cytoperm solution, transfer to a round bottom 96-well plate and incubate at 4°C for 20 min to fix
Pellet cells at 500 × g and 4°C for 5 min and wash twice in 100 μL of Perm/Wash buffer
Note: Make sure to dilute 10× Perm/Wash buffer to a 1× solution in distilled water
Stain cells for expression of ISG15
Pellet cells at 500 × g and 4°C for 5 min, resuspend in 50 μL of mouse anti-ISG15 diluted 1:10 in Perm/Wash buffer and incubate at 4°C for 30 min
Pellet cells at 500 × g and 4°C for 5 min and wash twice with 100 μL of Perm/Wash buffer
Pellet cells at 500 × g and 4°C for 5 min and resuspend in 50 μL of APC-conjugated anti-mouse diluted 1:100 in Perm/Wash buffer and incubate at 4°C for 30 min in the dark
Pellet cells at 500 × g and 4°C for 5 min, wash twice with 100 μL of Perm/Wash buffer and resuspend cells in 1 mL of sorting buffer
Note: Antibody dilutions should be optimized by the user to minimize background staining
Measure single cell fluorescence using Beckman Coulter MoFlo XDP (or similar flow analyzer)

Set FSC/SSC gate and the negative gate for ISG15 expression and GFP using mock treated cells
Run cells stained with anti-ISG15 and APC-conjugated anti-mouse to quantify expression of ISG15 and GFP in fixed and permeabilized cells
Note: If cell numbers are reduced prior to or during flow cytometry refer to troubleshooting 2 - Low cell count[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3]. If GFP fluorescence is too low or background fluorescence too high to detect changes in fluorescence refer to troubleshooting 5 - Low GFP fluorescence[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9] or troubleshooting 6 - High background fluorescence[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.11].
Critical: Be careful to avoid exposing fixed cells to light as GFP and APC-conjugated antibody are light sensitive
Detecting IFN production by fluorescence microscopy
Timing: 5 h
Fluorescence microscopy is useful to visualize production of IFN and other molecules in an intact cell monolayer or for intracellular localization. To see whether IFN-producing cells cluster or are associated with higher levels of SeV infection, we used fluorescence microscopy of stained coverslips.
Formalin fix and permeabilize cells
Wash cells with PBS, add 1 mL of 10% formalin per well and incubate for 10 min at 23°C away from direct light
Remove formalin and wash off any excess formalin with PBS
Add 1 mL of 0.2% Tx-100 in PBS per well and incubate for 10 min at 23°C away from direct light
Wash cells with PBS, add 1 mL of IF blocking buffer per well and incubate 1 h at 4°C in the dark
Pause Point: Permeabilized coverslips can be left overnight in blocking buffer at 4°C in the dark
Stain cells with SeV- and ISG15-specific antibodies
Dilute mouse anti-SeV 1:2000 and mouse anti-ISG15 1:50 seperately in IF blocking buffer
Remove IF blocking buffer and use forceps to center coverslips within the well

Add just enough diluted antibody to cover the coverslip (∼30 μL, surface tension should keep it from running off) and incubate for 1 h in the dark
Dilute Alexa Fluor 594-conjugated anti-mouse IgG (Invitrogen) 1:500 and Alexa Fluor 488-conjugated anti-GFP (invitrogen) 1:1000 together in IF blocking buffer
Wash 3 times with PBS and once with IF blocking buffer
The IF blocking buffer wash is necessary to keep the secondary antibody on the coverslip
Center the coverslip, add just enough secondary antibody to cover the coverslip (∼30 ul) and incubate 1 h in the dark
Dilute Hoechst 33342 1:5000 in PBS
Wash with PBS, add 0.5 mL of Hoechst per well and incubate 10 min in the dark
Note: Antibody dilutions should be optimized by the user to minimize background staining
Mount coverslips on slides
Discard Hoechst, wash 3 times with PBS and once with water to avoid salt crystalizing
Note: Make sure to properly dispose of Hoechst and the first PBS wash
Add ∼3 μL of mounting medium to slides where the coverslips will be placed
Using forceps carefully lift the coverslips, blot excess liquid from the edges and lower the coverslips onto the mounting medium so as to avoid trapping air bubbles as much as possible
Pause Point: With proper anti-fade mounting media, coverslips can be kept at 4°C and should maintain fluorescence for at least a few days.
Visualize cells with a fluorescence microscope
Note: If GFP fluorescence is too low or background fluorescence too high to detect changes in fluorescence refer to troubleshooting 5 - Low GFP fluorescence[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9] or troubleshooting 6 - High background fluorescence[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.11].
Critical: Be careful to avoid exposing fixed cells to light during incubations as GFP and other fluorophores are light sensitive.
